name: Enhanced Plumage
description: Develop more elaborate feathers for insulation and display.

scientificBasis.description: Feather evolution occurred gradually from simple filaments to complex pennaceous feathers used for thermoregulation, display, and eventually flight.
scientificBasis.evidence: Fossil evidence from the Jehol Biota shows progressive feather complexity in theropods from Sinosauropteryx to Microraptor.

gameplayNote: Recommended for cold biomes and social encounters.

name: Dense Ossification
description: Develop denser, more robust bones for improved durability.

scientificBasis.description: Pachyostosis (bone thickening) evolved independently in various lineages, particularly in aquatic or semi-aquatic species for buoyancy control.
scientificBasis.evidence: Spinosaurus displays pachyostotic bones, interpreted as adaptation for swimming and diving.

name: Pneumatic Skeleton
description: Develop air-filled hollow bones for reduced weight and improved agility.

scientificBasis.description: Pneumatization of the skeleton is a key theropod adaptation that reduced body mass while maintaining structural integrity, eventually enabling flight in birds.
scientificBasis.evidence: CT scans of theropod fossils reveal extensive pneumatic cavities connected to the respiratory system.

gameplayNote: Ideal for scout and flying roles.

name: Acute Olfaction
description: Develop enlarged olfactory bulbs for enhanced scent detection.

scientificBasis.description: Tyrannosaurs and other theropods possessed enormous olfactory bulbs, suggesting a highly developed sense of smell comparable to modern vultures.
scientificBasis.evidence: Endocast studies of T. rex skulls show olfactory bulbs proportionally larger than any living terrestrial vertebrate.

name: Stereo Vision
description: Develop forward-facing eyes with overlapping visual fields for depth perception.

scientificBasis.description: Predatory theropods evolved forward-facing eyes with significant binocular overlap, enabling precise distance judgment essential for hunting.
scientificBasis.evidence: Skull morphology of T. rex shows 55° binocular overlap, exceeding modern hawks.

name: Lateral Vision
description: Develop laterally-placed eyes for nearly 360° field of view.

scientificBasis.description: Herbivorous dinosaurs typically had laterally-placed eyes providing wide visual coverage to detect approaching predators.
scientificBasis.evidence: Skull anatomy of hadrosaurs and ceratopsians shows eye sockets positioned for maximum peripheral vision.

name: Aquatic Sensory Pits
description: Develop specialized sensory pits on the snout for detecting prey movement in water.

scientificBasis.description: Spinosaurids possessed neurovascular foramina on their snouts similar to crocodilians, suggesting pressure-sensing capability for aquatic hunting.
scientificBasis.evidence: High-resolution CT scans of Spinosaurus snout reveal extensive neurovascular channels consistent with integumentary sensory organs.

name: Venom Production
description: Develop modified salivary glands capable of producing toxic compounds.

scientificBasis.description: While controversial, some theropods may have possessed venom-delivering capabilities. Sinornithosaurus had grooved teeth suggesting venom delivery.
scientificBasis.evidence: Sinornithosaurus skull analysis revealed grooved teeth and a potential venom gland space, though interpretation remains debated.

name: Resonating Crest
description: Develop a hollow cranial crest for producing low-frequency sounds.

scientificBasis.description: Lambeosaurine hadrosaurs possessed elaborate hollow crests that functioned as resonating chambers for producing distinctive calls.
scientificBasis.evidence: Digital reconstruction of Parasaurolophus crest produced low-frequency sounds in the 30-240 Hz range, traveling kilometers.

gameplayNote: Enhances support abilities and team coordination.

name: Dorsal Sail
description: Develop elongated neural spines forming a prominent sail for thermoregulation and display.

scientificBasis.description: Sails evolved independently in Spinosaurus, Dimetrodon, and other taxa. Functions include thermoregulation, display, and fat storage.
scientificBasis.evidence: Bone histology and blood vessel traces in Spinosaurus neural spines indicate high vascularization consistent with thermoregulation.

name: Dermal Ossification
description: Develop bony deposits in the skin forming protective armor plates.

scientificBasis.description: Osteoderms (dermal armor) evolved in multiple dinosaur lineages including ankylosaurs, titanosaurs, and some theropods.
scientificBasis.evidence: Ankylosaurid osteoderms were fused to the dermis, forming a continuous armor layer with over 1000 individual elements.

gameplayNote: Significant defensive upgrade with mobility cost.

name: Hyperextended Claw
description: Develop an enlarged, curved claw on the second toe for slashing attacks.

scientificBasis.description: Dromaeosaurid sickle claws were hyperextensible, held off the ground during locomotion and deployed during attacks.
scientificBasis.evidence: Biomechanical studies suggest the claw was used for slashing and gripping rather than climbing or disemboweling.

name: Caudal Osteoderm Fusion
description: Develop fused osteoderms at the tail tip forming a bony club.

scientificBasis.description: Ankylosaurid tail clubs are composed of fused osteoderms and enlarged caudal vertebrae, forming an effective defensive weapon.
scientificBasis.evidence: Impact simulations estimate ankylosaurid tail clubs could generate 14,000+ Newtons of force, sufficient to fracture bone.

name: Cranial Thickening
description: Develop a massively thickened skull dome for head-butting combat.

scientificBasis.description: Pachycephalosaur skull domes could exceed 25cm thickness of solid bone, though the biomechanics of head-butting remain debated.
scientificBasis.evidence: Histological analysis shows the dome is composed of dense, structurally reinforced bone unsuitable for head-on impacts, suggesting flank-butting.

gameplayNote: Specialized combat adaptation with intelligence trade-off.

name: Ontogenetic Gigantism
description: Undergo accelerated growth to reach massive adult size.

scientificBasis.description: Dinosaur gigantism evolved through rapid growth rates, with some species gaining over 2kg per day during adolescence.
scientificBasis.evidence: Bone histology of T. rex shows growth rates of 2.1 kg/day during the teenage growth spurt, reaching adult size by ~20 years.

gameplayNote: Major stat overhaul for powerhouse builds.

name: Insular Dwarfism
description: Evolve smaller body size for resource-limited environments.

scientificBasis.description: Island dwarfism occurred in several dinosaur lineages, with isolated populations evolving smaller body sizes due to limited resources.
scientificBasis.evidence: Magyarosaurus, a Romanian titanosaur, was only 6m long compared to 20m+ mainland relatives, representing island dwarfism.

name: Social Intelligence
description: Develop enhanced social cognition for coordinated group behavior.

scientificBasis.description: Evidence for coordinated pack hunting in dromaeosaurids suggests complex social cognition and communication.
scientificBasis.evidence: The Deinonychus-Tenontosaurus association at various sites suggests coordinated attacks on large prey.

name: Apex Predator Instincts
description: Develop enhanced individual hunting capabilities for solitary apex predation.

scientificBasis.description: Adult tyrannosaurs likely transitioned to solitary hunting as they reached apex predator status in their ecosystems.
scientificBasis.evidence: Size disparity between juvenile and adult tyrannosaurs suggests ontogenetic niche partitioning and solitary adult behavior.

name: Scotopic Vision
description: Develop enlarged eyes with enhanced rod photoreceptors for night hunting.

scientificBasis.description: Some theropods possessed enlarged scleral rings indicating large eyes adapted for low-light conditions.
scientificBasis.evidence: Troodon's large orbits and sclerotic ring proportions suggest adaptation for nocturnal or crepuscular activity.

name: Elevated Metabolism
description: Develop a higher metabolic rate for increased activity levels.

scientificBasis.description: Growing evidence suggests dinosaurs had metabolic rates intermediate between modern reptiles and birds, enabling sustained activity.
scientificBasis.evidence: Bone histology showing rapid growth rates and LAGs (lines of arrested growth) indicates endothermic or mesothermic physiology.

gameplayNote: Higher performance with increased resource needs.

name: Inertial Homeothermy
description: Maintain stable body temperature through sheer mass rather than metabolic heat.

scientificBasis.description: Large dinosaurs could maintain stable internal temperatures through thermal inertia, independent of environmental fluctuations.
scientificBasis.evidence: Isotopic analysis of dinosaur teeth shows stable body temperatures across different latitudes and seasons.

gameplayNote: Passive temperature regulation for large creatures.
